pathway.warning: If baseline hematologic studies show thromboctopenia, coagulopathy or unexplained anemia, refer the patient urgently to hematology and do not start anticoagulation.  If the patient is pregnant, she should be urgently referred to a specialist in the management of women who are pregnant and require anticoagulation.
pathway.exclusions:
This UpToDate Pathway is not appropriate for patients with any of the following exclusions:
  • Age <18 years
  • Anticipated cardioversion or catheter ablation of atrial fibrillation in the next 4 weeks
  • Receiving a parenteral anticoagulant(eg. heparin or low molecular weight haparin)
  • Pregnant or breastfeeding
  • Indications for anticoagulation in addition to atrial fibrillation
    - Deep vein thrombosis
    - Pulmonary embolism
    - thrombophia
    - Intracardiac thrombus
  • Specific types of heart disease/surgery
    • - Mitral stenosis
    - Prosthetic heart valve (mechanical or bioprosthetic)
    - History of rheumatic heart disease
    - Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
  • Hematologic abnormalities
    • - Thrombocytopenia
    - Coagulopathy (not due to anticoagulant use)
    - Unexplained anemia
  • Significant renal disease
    - End stage renal disease
    - Acute kidney injury
    - Creatnine clearance <30 mL/min
  • Hepatic impairment
    • - Cirrhosis
    - Significant hepatic fibrosis
    - Hepatic synthetic dysfunction
  • High bleeding risk
    • - Planned or recent (within 72 hours) procedure with high risk of bleeding (major surgery, neuraxial procedure)
    - Known bleeding disorder
    - Prolonged prothrombin time or INR >1.2 (not due to warfarin use)
    - Suspected aortic dissection
    - Large abdominal aortic aneurysm
    - frequent falls
    - Active alcohol abuse
    - Active bleeding (non-menstrual) or recent major bleeding (within 2 weeks)
  • Risk factors for intracranial bleeding
    • - Severe uncontrolled hypertension (ie, systolic >180 mmHg and/or diastolic > 120 mmHg)
    - Prior intracranial hemorrhage
    - Known cerebrovascular malformation
    - Known malignant intracranial neoplasm
    - Significant closed head trauma within 3 months

questions.question: Is this UpToDate Pathway appropriate for this patient?

options.label: Yes
No

questions.content:
Scope

This Interactive Clinical Guideline will help determine if an adult with non-valvular atrial fibrillation is likely to benefit from chronic oral anticoagulation and guide clinicians in the appropriate choice of an oral anticoagulant for a given patient.

Last updated 02/07/2017

Required Tests

The following test results may be required to answer the questions that will follow:
  • Serum creatinine/creatinine clearance
In addition, the following test results should be available prior to starting a patient on an anticoagulant:
  • Prothrombin time (PT)/international normalized ratio (INR)
  • Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 
  • Complete blood count
  • Quantitative serum human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) pregnancy test (for women who might be pregnant)
questions.warning: This UpToDate Pathway is not appropriate for this patient because one or more exclusions are present. For additional information on the approach to patients not covered by this UpToDate Pathway, please refer to Related UpToDate Content. Close the browser tab to exit the UpToDate Pathway

questions.question: Patient's sex
questions.content:
In order to determine if anticoagulation may be appropriate for a given patient, the patient's stroke risk and bleeding risk should be estimated.

  • The risk of stroke can be estimated using the CHA2DS2-VASc score
  • The risk of bleeding can be estimated using the HAS-BLED score

CHA2DS2-VASc score.

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to estimate a patient's stroke risk. Scores range from 0 (estimated annual stroke risk of 0.2%) to 9 (estimated annual stroke risk of 12.2%). However, the stroke rate can vary based on the study setting (eg, community versus hospitalized), the patient population studied, and the study methodology.The CHA2DS2-VASc score and estimated stroke risk based on the score are meant to provide guidance, but are not substitutes for clinical judgment.

options.label: Male
Female
<65 years
65 to 74 years
>=75 years
Decompensated heart failure
Hypertension
Diabetes Melitus
History of stroke, transient ischemic attack, thromboembolism
Vascular disease
None of the above

pathway.statement: Anticoagulation is NOT suggested for most patients with a score of 0~Do you want to start/continue anticoagulation for this patient

questions.question: Do you want to start/continue anticoagulation?

options.label: Yes start/continue anticoagulation
No do not start/continue anticoagulation

questions.content:
Anticoagulation is not suggested for most patients with a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 0.

For patients with a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 0, the estimated annual stroke risk is 0.2% and the benefit-to-risk ratio generally does not favor anticoagulation. Nevertheless, a patient who is particularly stroke averse and is not at increased risk for bleeding may reasonably choose anticoagulation.

This patient's HAS-BLED score is 1, which is associated with a bleeding risk of 1.02 bleeds per 100 patient-years.

Characteristics that have been associated with an increased risk of bleeding include:
  • Increased age (variously reported as >60 to >80 years)
  • Female sex
  • Prior stroke or intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Previous severe hemorrhage during treatment with warfarin with an INR in the therapeutic range
  • Comorbid illnessess: Diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hepatic dysfunction, renal dysfunction, malignancy, anemia
  • For patients on warfarin: poor drug compliance, irregular clinic attendance, or instability of INR control
  • Bleeding disorder (eg, coagulation defect, thrombocytopenia) or pretreatment INR >1.2
  • Concomitant use of aspirin, an NSAID, or an antiplatelet agent (eg, clopidogrel)

pathway.statement: What if any, anticoagulant is the~patient taking for atrail fibrillation?

questions.question: Choose a treatment approach

options.label: Order medications individually

addSummary.value: A PPI, bismuth, a tetracycline derivative, and metronidazole will be used

options.label: Order a proton pump inhibitor plus a combination pill (Pylera)
Approach other than the options provided (this approach may differ from the recommendations of UpToDate)

addSummary.value: Approach other than the options provided

questions.content:
Quadruple therapy for 14 days is appropriate for this patient. (Additional information)

Quadruple therapy can be administered by providing each agent individually or by providing a PPI plus a combination pill (Pylera), which combines bismuth and the two antibiotics into a single pill. Combination pills may improve adherence, but may also be more expensive.

Quadruple therapy includes:
  • A proton pump inhibitor (PPI)
  • Bismuth
  • A tetracycline derivative
  • Metronidazole
questions.addInfoContent:
• Patients should be informed that adherence to treatment is a critical factor in determining the success of eradication therapy. 
  • Because the regimen includes metronidazole, strict alcohol avoidance should be advised.

questions.content: Important drug dosing information
questions.addInfoContent: The drug doses given generally represent the doses that are suggested for patients who do not require dose adjustments due to factors such as comorbid illnesses, organ dysfunction, drug interactions, or other reasons. In addition, some of the medications used in this UpToDate Pathway should not be used concurrently with other medications because of drug interactions, so the interacting medication may need to be held during therapy or an alternative antibiotic regimen chosen (refer to UpToDate content for more details on alternative regimens). Consult a clinical drug reference, appropriate UpToDate topic reviews, and/or other resources to confirm the appropriate dosing for a given patient.

options.label: Esomeprazole 40 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Esomeprazole 20 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Lansoprazole 30 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Omeprazole 20 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Pantoprazole 40 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Rabeprazole 20 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Proton pump inhibitor at a dose or frequency other than the options provided (this approach may differ from the recommendations of UpToDate)

questions.content: Choose a PPI (Additional information)
questions.addInfoContent: If esomeprazole is chosen, it can either be given as 40 mg once daily or 20 mg twice daily. The Toronto Consensus guideline considers 20 mg twice daily to be the standard dose for the treatment of H. pylori.

questions.question: Select a tetracycline derivative.

options.label: Tetracycline 500 mg orally four times daily for 14 days (preferred if available)
Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 14 days
Tetracycline-derivative at a dose or frequency other than the options provided (this approach may differ from the recommendations of UpToDate)

questions.content: <hr>

questions.question: Select bismuth subsalicylate.

options.label: Bismuth subsalycilate 524 mg orally four times daily for 14 days
Bismuth subsalycilate at a dose or frequency other than the option provided (this approach may differ from the recommendations of UpToDate)

questions.content: <hr>

questions.question: Select metronidazole.
questions.summaryOverview: The drug doses given in this UpToDate Pathway generally represent the doses that are suggested for patients who do not require dose adjustments due to factors such as comorbid illnesses, organ dysfunction, drug interactions, or other reasons. Consult a clinical drug reference, appropriate UpToDate topic reviews, and/or other resources to confirm the appropriate dosing for a given patient. options.label: Metronidazole 250 mg orally four times daily for 14 days
Metronidazole at a dose or frequency other than the option provided (this approach may differ from the recommendations of UpToDate)

questions.content: <hr>

questions.question: Choose a testing approach.
questions.summaryOverview: Confirmation of H. pylori eradication can be obtained with a stool or breath test. For patients who are scheduled for an upper endoscopy following treatment, eradication can be determined at the time of endoscopy. Testing should be done at least 4 weeks after treatment is completed. Patients should not take a PPI or bismuth for 4 weeks prior to confirmation testing.

options.label: H. pylori urea breath test
H. pylori stool antigen test
Eradication will be confirmed during upper endoscopy
Refer to gastroenterology for eradicatin confirmation
Refer to infectious disease specialist for eradicatin confirmation
Eradication confirmation using an approach other than options provided (this approach may differ from the recommendations of UpToDate)

questions.content: Confirmation of H. pylori eradication by stool or breath test following treatment is recommended. (Additional information)
questions.addInfoContent:
Confirmation of H. pylori eradication by stool or breath test following treatment is recommended. For patients who are scheduled for an upper endoscopy following treatment, eradication can be determined at the time of endoscopy. For other patients, an H. pylori test should be done at least 4 weeks after treatment is completed. Patients should not take a PPI or bismuth for 4 weeks prior to confirmation testing.

Note, in patients with peptic ulcers, antisecretory therapy with a PPI may need to be continued for more than 4 weeks (thus delaying eradication confirmation). For patients with complicated duodenal ulcers (eg, ulcers with bleeding, gastric outlet obstruction, ulcer penetration, or perforation), the PPI should be continued for 4 to 8 weeks. For patients with gastric ulcers, the PPI should be continued for 8 to 12 weeks.

mainTitle: Atrial Fibrillation: Anticoagulation for adults with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation
